Nicholes WongLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 14 Sep 2018I feel that it depends. Because warchest have to be very liquid. Very liquid means lower interest. Imagine you put your warchest in SSB and you have to wait at least 1 month to get it out, you would have miss out on the profits. Also if you have a warchest too big, you are wasting the potential compound interest you can earn. If warchest too small, you wont profit much during market corrections.0 comments2

Yong Kah HweeLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 15 Sep 2018It really depends on which stage of life you are at, and how much money you need each month. If you are young and have no bills to pay for, you can afford to put more of your money inside stocks/bonds/etc. Conversely, if you are at the stage whereby you have housing loans to pay, parents and children to feed (ie many dependants), then you might want to consider allocating a larger part of your portfolio towards your warchest in case of rainy days!0 comments1
